HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary

Scenario Description : Release of the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in a vessel (the High Pressure Receiver has the capacity to hold 10,448 pounds) in 10 minutes.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F stability.  Since the HPR vessel is located inside, the enclosure of the building was considered a passive mitigation measure, reducing the effective release rate to the outside atmosphere by 55%.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches 0.9 miles off site and may impact population receptors.  A city park is also in the 0.9 mile radius zone.

Alternative Release Result Summary

Scenario Description : The alternative release scenario presented is similar to the worst case in that it is a liquid release.  The alternative release scenario chosen for this facility is that of a 0.25 inch diameter orifice leading to an airborne release, representative of a pump seal leak, a gasket rupture, pinhole leak due to corrosion, flange seal leak, valve bonnet seal leak, etc.  It is assumed that this release is from the high side of the system; therefore at a maximum pressure of 180 psig.  The release scenario is assumed to continue until the full charge is released, thereby incorporating mitigation measures such as the ammonia sensors and system shutdown.

EPA allows a facility to use typical meteorological conditions at the facility. For this scenario, a wind speed of 3 meters/second and neutral conditions, D stability, were used to find the distance the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in a urban area.

EPA's

Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities, Exhibit 4-5 for D Stability, Wind Speed 3.0 Meters per Second, was used to find the downwind distance for the alternate release scenario. This release reaches 0.1 miles off site.  No population or environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The WestFarm Foods ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP). 

Ammonia detectors are strategically located in the engine room.  In case of ammonia detection, visible and audible alarms will activate at the facility and at the computer system.

In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, evaporator fans shut-down, etc.).

The system also incorporates a pressure relief line.  In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent to a common header which relieves to the atmosphere.  This mechanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

WestFarm Foods has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the WestFarm Foods' PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

WestFarm Foods maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.

WestFarm Foods has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, the Portland Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of WestFarm Foods to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

WestFarm Foods began operation at the facility in 1978.  The ammonia system at WestFarm Foods consists primarily of vessels, compressors, condensers, evaporators and associated piping.  The majority of the equipment is located inside the engine room.  The system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator.  There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.

The WestFarm Foods facility provides cold storage space and a docking area for warehouse items.  Ammonia sensors are located in the Engine Room and Warehouse that alert facility personnel and activate the ventilation system in the engine room and close all feed lines out of

R01 - Reduce ammonia volume according to existing reduction plan.
R02 - Conduct an ammonia awareness training program that includes informing all employees of the following: 1) the presence of and the hazards associated with ammonia at the facility, 2) how to recognize the odor, 3) what to do if they observe an ammonia leak, and 4) where to go when they are told to evacuate.
R03 - Develop safe practices by having eye protection, ear protection, gloves, protective clothing, etc. available for use by maintenance.
R04 - Determine the level at which the detector will shut down the system.  Consider replacing the existing detector with one that will alarm at a low concentration level and shut the system down at a higher concentration level.
R05 - Follow manufacturer's recommended maintenance schedule to test, and if necessary, calibrate ammonia detectors.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.
R06 - Train all maintenance operators and appropriate supervisors as to the appropriate procedure to follow if an ammonia release occur.
R07 - Use same evacuation procedures and conduct annual evacuation drills for fire and ammonia.
R08 - Establish a policy whereby, in the event of any leak in the engine room, the system is shut down.  If the leak is in a room in the plant, shut down the feed to that room and allow the compressors to draw the ammonia vapor back from the room.
R09 - Consider the feasability of adding necessary valving in order to isolate the condensers.
R10 - Implement a policy so that combustible material, such as pallets and extra oil are not stored in the engine room or in the vicinity of any ammonia refrigeration equipment.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental ammonia releases at the WestFarm Foods facility within the last five years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

WestFarm Foods has an emergency action plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the City of Portland Fire Department and the local fire houses.  In case of a major ammonia emergency, the facility will first call 9-1-1 to alert the local Police and Fire Departments.  Other responders will be called as needed, including the Department of Public Safety Emergency Management Services.  If a release exceeds the federal reporting quantity of 100 pounds for ammonia, the National Response Center and the Emergency Spill Report Sensor will be called.

WestFarm Foods maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to renovation of the facility.

WestFarm Foods will be responsible for evacuating and ensuring the safety of its employees and will coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.
